Fields.DialogueText: Gah! Kapitan, do watch where you're going!
The problem is on your end, Boiky. You can't take up the whole starboard with whatever it is you're doing.
Necessary evil, Kapitan! I may be strong, but these B-13s are bulky.

Fields.MenuText: Stop messing with them. You don't know when you'll get an upgrade.
The barrels alone weigh over five tons. Think of the crew's safety.
Whatever you do, can you at least do it in port?

Fields.DialogueText: They'll have to be replaced anyway after our next battle! I may as well try to better them now.
I always do! They've learned to stay away when I'm working.
If I do, I don't get to try the really interesting modifications!
We've had this conversation before. You can't spend your patrols "repairing" yourself.
Then I--
Or using islands and allies for target practice.
That was just the few times!
Don't you ever just sit still and keep watch?
Odnazhdy. Then I got bored, fixed a gun, and blew up a rock.
Mark my words, I'll find something you can sink your energy into. You can't fight Morganas every waking moment.
What about when I'm asleep?
Dreams don't count.
Exactly why I must fight when I am awake!
Here's your chance now. It looks like Morganas are on the prowl. Not that we needed their help to derail this discussion.
Kakaya udacha! They're on my good side.
@BATTLE
Okay, let's see. You must have other hobbies. What are you interested in?
Weapons and weapon maintenance!
That's good, but what else?
The violent overthrow of the old bourgeois order!
That's not really a hobby.
Well, it ought to be! How else are we to unite the nations of the world?

Fields.MenuText: Don't go looking for enemies, Boiky.
I really don't have an answer for that.
We're getting off track. I've got to point you at something.

Fields.DialogueText: I never have to, my sweet Kapitan! They all seem to find me easily enough.
That's why you have me around!
Please do! It's been too long since I last blew up something.
Let's see, let's see... You sing, right?
Kapitan, how did you know? I only sing in the showers...
That's it! You must have been spying! Perverted swine!
Put that down! You sing in your sleep all the time.
Stand still so I can... I do?
The Internationale seems to be a favorite of yours.
It is, isn't it? Please forgive me, Kapitan! I should not have jumped to conclusions.
So, can you perhaps sing more and destroy less?
Hmm... I will try, Kapitan, but I am a destroyer, after all. It's what I do!
Think it over while you do what you do best to these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Lish? My, rabotniki vsemirnoy--
Boiky, do you remember when I told you you needed a hobby?
Clear as these skies, my dear Kapitan!
As in something you do in your spare time.
Da, and your suggestion was perfect!
You've been singing nonstop.
I find that the patriotic songs do amazing things for morale! If some is good, more is better, ne tak li?

Fields.MenuText: In theory, yes. In practice, not so much.
For the crew's sake, I need you to be less patriotic.
If you don't give us some peace and quiet, you're in drydock.

Fields.DialogueText: But, it's simple arithmetic! Where does it break down?
Kapitan, if I were religious, I'd say that borders on heresy!
Da. I was only trying to help...
Do you do anything in moderation?
I don't believe in it! There's nothing worth doing that can't be done bigger and better.
We'll have to find something else that keeps you occupied. You're making it difficult to sleep.
Humanity's only weakness! What if I cured it?
What if we all collapsed from exhaustion?
Ya ponimayu. Are we in fighting shape for these Morgana?
We're going to have to be.
@BATTLE
Velikoy armii truda--
Vladet? Zemlyoy imeyem pravo--
No parazity-- nikogda!
Is that singing?
That's singing. Boiky?
You've been awfully quiet these past few days.
Hard at work on this latest project, Kapitan.
Should I be worried?
Only if you fear effortless victory!
So... Yes.
Behold!
It's a drawing of you throwing a javelin at a Morgana.
Not quite a javelin. Remember, my B-13s can't shoot a whole magazine without the barrel being replaced! I've got to do something with the spent ones.

Fields.MenuText: You can throw them? But, you're so... small.
That doesn't strike you as dangerous?
I think Moscow has other ideas for disposal.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm also a destroyer. Pack that strength into a body this size and see how forceful I can be!
Why wouldn't it? Victory requires a monopoly on violence!
Da, but Moscow is only a city.
It's taken you this long to draw a picture?
Oh, I only handed you the first page. Behold again!
Ah.
All my calculations!
All... Eighty-three, eighty-four... Three hundred and ninety-six pages.
Ordinarily, I'd just do it, but I thought you might appreciate some forethought. Then I wondered how the wind would affect my throw, then point of origin, and... Well, here we are!
We're receiving reports of Morgana activity. I'll discuss your plans with Command after the battle and see what they have to say, all right?
I suppose that would be the responsible thing to do...
I'll just... Put these in your quarters, then.
Nyet! That is the one thing I must insist against.
If you say so.
@BATTLE
There's another Morgana, Boiky. Have you read the communique from--
It's going to have to wait, Kapitan! These are weather conditions I thought I could only dream of!
Boiky, it concerns your--
Stand back, pozhaluysta!
@BATTLE
You can explain this one to the Commissariat.
With pride!
With apologies. If you'd let me finish earlier... Oh, just read it.
From the Naval Commissariat? Ooh, it's from Kuznetsov himself!
Oh... I see.
There's procedure for disposing of materiel. Next time you want to get rid of your spent barrels, let the supply ships take care of it.
To be melted into scrap and recast into bullets that will be fired from faulty weapons, destined only for trees and rocks! Kapitan, I could use them to strike down Rusalki now!

Fields.MenuText: Aren't we trying to keep you from destroying trees and rocks?
I sympathize with you, Boiky.
Take a deep breath.

Fields.DialogueText: This is getting me upset.
At least I know you are a true Comrade, Kapitan. Spasibo, my dear.
Stop being reasonable! I am angry, can't you tell?
Back to the drawing board, Boiky.
Checkmate.
V zaklyucheniye. Is that the lesson for the day?

Fields.MenuText: I thought all the Soviet Belles liked chess.
That depends. Are you going to throw more materiel overboard?
There's no need to be a sore loser.

Fields.DialogueText: Talk to Leningrad if you want a game. It is a pale imitation of the real thing.
Do chessboards count as materiel?
Victory was yours the minute I agreed to this travesty!
Oh, come on. Your country has a strong chess tradition. Did you know Ivan the Terrible died playing chess?
Of boredom, I can only assume.
No, but--
And, these pieces! Kings, queens, bishops? What imperialist nonsense is this? Am I to take pride in my hardworking pawns joining the ranks of their oppressors?
I think you're taking this game a little too literally. Although, that does explain that early queen sacrifice...
I'll show you a sacrifice!
Boiky! Put that down!
Otkrytyy ogon'!
Well, it's not like I need that piece to beat you.
Queen to Rusalka's left eye! Oh, Kapitan, this *is* fun!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All right. We've determined that you don't really like chess...
I said I was sorry, Kapitan.
And, I've had you tone down the singing.
Do stop pacing, Kapitan, you'll wear a hole in my deck!
I'm just thinking out loud. Hmm...
If your sisters were here, what would you do to entertain yourselves?
Oh! Well, we'd fight over the privilege of picking a target, and then we'd--

Fields.MenuText: Remind me to keep you girls separated.
Are your family reunions normally so violent?
Right. Thinking out loud again.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Our revolutionary spirit is no weaker in pieces!
Aren't yours?
Pah! Guns fire louder.
When we can go on patrol without destroying something that belongs to our side, I'll be happy.
Oh, speaking of which...
No. Please.
But, Kapitan, those Rusalki we are tailing could have used those trees on that island as cover!
What if she used the curvature of the planet as cover?
Well...
Don't answer that. Just do what you do best.
@BATTLE
Chert! Light, damn you, light!
What are we burning this time?
Kapitan, privyet! Please help me with this, I was never good at matches.
More old propaganda, I take it?
More old propaganda. You would think the crew would appreciate it!

Fields.MenuText: There's only so much you can do with drawings in battle.
At least it's keeping you busy.
Is that supposed to be a spider?

Fields.DialogueText: That is the disadvantage of their not being guns.
For the moment, Kapitan, but I grow bored of simply disposing of things...
It's a Rusalka! It's, um... Symbolic! Da, that's what it is.
You don't preserve anything you create?
Why should I? The world has no room for the outmoded and obsolete.
Not even to serve as an example?
Even a modification of the previous failure can be a shackle. Sometimes one must wipe clean the slate and start anew!
Those who don't learn from history...
... will write their own!
Maybe. But it might look familiar.
You worry too much.
Ah! There we go. Spasibo, Kapitan.
Didn't we talk about lighting bonfires on deck?
Perhaps we did. We must have been distracted by Rusalki. Ah, and speak of the devil, there are some now!
What was that about repeating oneself?
@BATTLE
Boiky, just read it.
I would prefer not to.
It's a modern classic! One of my favorites, anyway.
You know I haven't any interest in literature!
How do you know until you try it?
Dragons, Kapitan? Goblins and wizards? What am I to do with these? We've got real monsters to fight!
I've seen the way you look at passing seagulls when we're not fighting monsters. Humor me, or you'll be firing blanks for the rest of the tour.
Grr... Fine. After I've slain this one.
The Morgana?
Nyet, the seagull. Of course I mean the Rusalka!
@BATTLE
Good shooting. You put on a good show, you know.
I hope so, Kapitan, seeing as it will be my last.

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean, your last?

Fields.DialogueText: Before I drift off to sleep forever... from reading.
You've got enough sweets to stay awake through at least the first couple of chapters.
Posmotrim.

Fields.MenuText: Melodramatic as ever.
Are all Russians so fatalistic?

Fields.DialogueText: But you find that quality of mine charming, don't you? Ah, maybe don't answer that...
Only the bored ones, Kapitan.
Maybe if you stayed close to me while I read it, I would not be so bored... but don't eat all of my sweets, Kapitan. I need them.
*sigh*
Finally, Rusalki to destroy and save me from my boredom!
@BATTLE
Enjoying the book so far?
Kapitan, if it were not yours I would have thrown it at those Rusalki!
That didn't stop you weaponizing my chess set.
Eto drugoye! It had greater military value than distracting me.

Fields.MenuText: That's for me to decide about my possessions.
Distracting you may be the greatest military value of all.
Sometimes, I hate when you're right.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, your personal property is your own... even if it is very frustrating.
Are you having fun with me, Kapitan? That sounded like a joke at my expense.
Don't fret, Kapitan! You will grow accustomed to it one day.
Well, I'll leave you to it. You sound like you're getting invested.
What gives you that silly idea?
The bookmark, for a start.
Which one? There are six.
I thought so.
Wait... Grr! Kapitan! Remove that smile at once!
I've finished the book you lent me!
So, that's where you've been all this time!
What do you mean, "all this time"?
You disappeared when I asked you how it was going. I haven't been able to find you for a while now.
Nevozmozhno! That would mean I've been hiding away with this book for...
Chert.

Fields.MenuText: I thought you weren't much of a reader.
You must have really liked it. I could recommend a couple more.
Well, I'd rather have you disappear than blowing up islands.

Fields.DialogueText: ... So did I, I must admit.
Nyet, Kapitan, not unless you want me to disappear again!
Hmph. Without me, this whole front would collapse!
You've got quite the addictive personality, it seems.
I guess I just hadn't found the right book, Kapitan. I hadn't expected it to be so... Revolutionary!
Revolutionary, you say?
Isn't it just, Kapitan? The small, rural folk stealing into the dragon's hoard to reclaim what rightfully belonged to the wandering dwarves? It simply screams for an uprising!
You are aware that the dwarves had a monarchy.
Ah, but this was written in the West! Meant to be read far and wide. And in a bourgeois environment, the revolutionaries must read between the lines!
I'm glad you found it so inspiring, at any rate.
Especially the part where the hero plays a game of riddles! Such ingenuity as could only have come from the working class...
Keep your mind on the fight today. We can discuss literature later.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Kapitan, have you heard the news? My anti-air guns are obsolete!
Already?
When our country's on a war footing, these things move fast! The shooting hadn't even started when my DShK-1938s went belt-fed. And thank goodness for that...
What are they rolling out now?
The 85mm 52-K! Those old 76mm guns are no longer fashionable. It even fires anti-armor shells! Mmmm...
I haven't seen you this excited since your Tula gingerbread came out of the oven.
Don't remind me, Kapitan! I won't be able to focus on these Morganas...
@BATTLE
Soooo... We're switching out the 76mms, da?
According to the Commissariat, not yet. It's like those old rifles you showed me. They want to get as much use out of the old model as possible first.
But, this one's better! Give me an 85mm and a forge and I'll melt these dinosaurs into shells for their replacements!

Fields.MenuText: I'll write to Kuznetsov and see what he can spare, but no promises.
Not until we're assigned one. You're too cavalier with your armaments as it is.
We can't make our own ammunition. Don't be ridiculous.

Fields.DialogueText: I hate waiting.
But, that's what they're for!
Don't be stubborn!
Here's something to keep you busy. What lives in the past, is made in the present, but is untouched by the future?
Kapitan, is this a riddle?
Like in the book. Feel like a challenge?
I love challenges! There's just something intriguing about the ones you can't blow up...
If you find a way, let me know. Better yet, don't.
Gah! Idite k chertu, i prinyat' vashi slabosti k vam!
Now, now. Be nice to your guns.
What harm is a curse now and again? I'll have to swap them out anyway!
You figure out the riddle yet?
I think so... but maybe it isn't the right answer.
What did you come up with?
History, Kapitan! Because it's in the past, and we're making history right now!
And, the future can't touch it. Good job.
Oh, but that is where I am confused! Of course the future can touch history.
How do you figure?
History may be reinterpreted as necessary, Kapitan! How do you think any revolution gains currency?
Military force and control of resources, for a start.
You put carts before horses, as Americans say. How are people to build their consciousness? Where will they see proof of concept but in the struggles that came before?
That doesn't change what actually happened.
Were you there?
Well, I--
Nor I! History may written by victors, but once they grow fat and lazy, it is *told* by revolutionaries. So you see, it cannot be the answer to your question.

Fields.MenuText: But it was my question.
Fine. What is the answer?
It's just a riddle, Boiky.

Fields.DialogueText: Until you posed it! Then it became common property.
Violence, of course! For human history is written in it, we commit such violence in the present as is strictly necessary, and in the future, it shall be a thing of the past.
A true revolutionary may draw inspiration from any source!
I suppose that's that one solved, then.
Nyet, Kapitan, I must come up with one of my own! Perhaps these Rusalki will inspire me!
@BATTLE
All right, Kapitan, this riddle will surely leave you scratching your head!
I thought every question was common property.
Wait and see if you can come up with a better answer. I will wager you cannot.
Shoot.
Why was six afraid of seven?

Fields.MenuText: Because seven "ate" nine. Everyone knows that.
I couldn't tell you.
Is this a riddle or a joke?

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Do not be so certain, Kapitan. Guess again.
Oh, you didn't even think about it! You must try harder.
Everything is funny from the right perspective!
Do I have to answer now? I gave you a while longer to answer mine.
I cannot wait, Kapitan!
Fine, I give up. Why was six afraid of seven?
Because seven has ties to the NKVD!
I... Didn't expect that.
Nobody does! That is why they are the secret police.
That's... That's some riddle, Boiky.
The best ones are the true ones!
Come up with another one, won't you?
Da! Right after we strip this Rusalka of her armor.
@BATTLE
Got another riddle for me, Boiky?
How did you know?
You're bouncing up and down with your notebook in your hand. It's that, or a new gingerbread recipe.
Clever, Kapitan, but your cleverness will do you no more favors! Read it and weep!
"A river."
Chert! Forget you ever saw anything, Kapitan!
You just showed me the answer, didn't you.
The answer to what? I haven't a clue what we're talking about!
Stop. I've got an idea. I'll just figure out what the question is.
The question... Kapitan, such a novel idea!

Fields.MenuText: What runs all day but never tires?
What has a mouth but does not eat?
Damn. I'm drawing a blank.

Fields.DialogueText: Close... But, not close enough!
Trotskyist propaganda! Oh, izvinite... Nyet, that is not the question!
Must you continue to disappoint me, Kapitan?
Ha! I knew you'd never guess it.
All right, I give up.
"What has a bed but does not sleep..."
Well, that was my second guess.
"... because it is filled with counterrevolutionary corpses?"
In fairness, I probably wouldn't have guessed that.
That is why I am winning two to one!
Um, why, look over there! Morganas. And an end to this conversation...
@BATTLE
You don't look pleased, Kapitan. Aren't you having fun spending time with me?
There, Kapitan! Do you see her?
Trying to sneak up on us, is she? She and her friends have made the Baltic islands practically unreachable. Are you ready?
For ages, Kapitan! Also, do have a bite, won't you?

Fields.MenuText: Cooking is your idea of preparing for battle?
Smells delicious. What is it?
No, thank you. I'm not hungry.

Fields.DialogueText: I do not fight on an empty stomach, and neither should you!
So glad you asked! I whipped up a whole platter of vatrushkas for us to share.
It's not about hunger, Kapitan, it's about energy!
Mmm. What's in these?
Is that today's riddle? It is all too easy! I thought I'd use some strawberries we had lying around, and--
I told you I'd think of one. Battle stations.
@BATTLE
Okay, listen closely. What is tall when it is young, and short when it is old?
Ooh, perplexing! Let's see... Is it a big plate of khvorost?
No, but what makes you say that?
Because there's less of it the more you eat!
Maybe you should get the cooking out of your system. I'll give you time to think on it.
Oh, just you wait! Nobody solves these things like I do!
I can't argue with that...
Kapitan, Kapitan, Kapitan! You'll never guess what I've guessed!

Fields.MenuText: I don't need to. You'll tell me.
Can it wait until I'm finished eating?
The revolution.

Fields.DialogueText: My secrets are not so easily pried out of me!
Nyet. Believe it or not, I operate by a strict schedule! I've only allocated three minutes to tease you this hour.
You know me too well... And, yet, not at all.
You're not seriously going to make me guess your answer.
No, actually, I'm not!... What was the question again?
You forgot the riddle.
Nyet! I was flipping through the dictionary, trying to find an answer, and I was halfway through K when I fell asleep and-- Oh! Speaking of K, any word on the 52-Ks?
What is tall when it is young and short when it is old?
Ah, of course! Izvinite, Kapitan. The answer is obviously a monarchy!
Oh, I can tell this will be good.
Indeed! For early in his reign, a king is high and mighty, full of divine right and all that... But, once he has ruled and the people grow restless, slash! He loses his head!
As entertaining as that is, I'm going to have to say no.
Nyet? Not a monarchy? Oh, then it must be a candle.
What the-- I mean, yes, but how do you get from one to--
The winds of change blow me in all sorts of directions, Kapitan!
Quite.
But, now, they blow us toward a filthy Rusalka! Let us deal death together!
@BATTLE
Don't work yourself too hard.
Zzz... Shiroka strana moya rodnaya... Zzz...
Boiky! You're setting a bad example.
Zzz... Political institutions are a superstructure on the economic foundation!
You don't say. Now wake up, Boiky. We've got a fight ahead of us.
@BATTLE
What's got you so exhausted lately? You haven't been shooting nearly as many islands as you usually do.
It's this riddle game you've sucked me into, Kapitan! I never thought I'd be reading this much, but it usually puts me to sleep anyway.

Fields.MenuText: As long as you're keeping yourself in top shape, I don't mind.
Even though you eat more sugar than a plague of locusts?
I should have known it would take a competition to get you to read.

Fields.DialogueText: The revolution is not only in the body, Kapitan, but in the mind!
Even locusts must rest their wings occasionally!
Sometimes I think I understand what capitalists mean about incentives...
Well, here's another one for you...
Do your worst, Kapitan!
What wakes up tomorrow, eats today, and sleeps yesterday?
Do understand that when I said "do your worst," I--
I'll wake you up tomorrow.
Gingerbread?
Da.
I figured you'd need it. How's the research coming?
Neudovletvoritel'no. What goes about its daily routine on different days? It is maddening!

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you're thinking about it too literally.
Maybe you should give it a rest. Come back with fresh eyes.
Have you thought about your own routine?

Fields.DialogueText: I will not rest until I've exhausted literalness itself!
And admit defeat to you? Nikogda!
Routines are for those with no enemies to disrupt them!
I could give you a hint if you like.
Certainly not! That would be like capitulating to my greatest ideological enemies.
It's just a riddle, Boiky.
That is easy for you to say. You are the one asking it!
Well, books down. We have Morganas headed this direction.
Will the world never cease to taunt me?
Could be worse. I could give you this letter to mail after the battle and tell you not to open it.
Kapitan, you hack mercilessly at the thin ice upon which you stand...
@BATTLE
Boiky, slow down! You almost knocked over--
They will pick themselves up! My lovely Kapitan, I've solved it! I've solved it!
Have you now?
It's clear as bulletproof glass! What wakes up tomorrow, eats today, sleeps yesterday? Obviously the sun, bringing the date with it!
Congratulations. You just correctly solved a riddle that doesn't exist.
What are you talking about? It makes perfect sense!
That's what surprises me. I was just saying words. I didn't expect you to come up with an answer.
Then... all this research... was for nothing?

Fields.MenuText: On the contrary. It kept you out of my hair while I got the real work done around here.

Fields.DialogueText: But, Kapitan... What have I been doing all this time? What could I have been doing instead of this nonsense?
Boiky? Boiky! There are Morganas out there!
Good! I need something to destroy!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I was just trying to entertain you.
If you had fun, it wasn't for nothing, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh...
I appreciate that you tried to entertain me. It shows that you care, even if you are careless.
I suppose...
Are you still angry?
Konechno. You deceived me into doing pointless things. That is energy I could have spent spreading the revolution!
I hardly think it was pointless. How many islands have you destroyed recently?
That is not the point!
Have you destroyed any?
Admittedly... Nyet. But, that does not change the fact that I could have!
Maybe you've just developed a better sense of self-control.
I should hope not! Communists disdain to conceal their views and aims.

Fields.MenuText: Your aim is to blow up the world?
Yet few of the other Soviet Belles are as violent as you.
For what it's worth, I'm proud of you.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, not without rebuilding it!
They are violent in different ways, Kapitan. It is the one way to revolutionize this world!
Proud of your own deceptions, you mean!
Say what you like. I've noticed you fighting differently, too. You don't just rush in guns blazing, you're more methodical. You actually wait for a decent shot... sometimes.
Do... Do I really? I mean, of course I do! That was my plan all along.
I think you've learned a lot, even if you don't feel that way. Tell you what - I got a response to this letter I had you mail. Read it.
From the Commissariat? Kapitan, you shouldn't have...
Go on.
Kapitan... this is...
The 52-Ks? They want... me to try them?
I promised them less friendly fire, and I got it. Congratulations, Boiky.
Kapitan... Spasibo!
Easy! You could kill a Morgana with that hug.
Could I? You really think so? Interesting...
No, that was just an--
Oh, if only I could leave the ship to try it on her!
@BATTLE
Battle stations, Boiky. These Morganas given us the slip for too long.
Da, Kapitan! Shall we draw them out or drive them out ourselves?

Fields.MenuText: They're hemmed in on all sides. No need for us to pursue further.
It's up to us to go in and finish the job.
What would you do, Boiky?

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Now who is the trapped one, and who is the trapper?
You speak my language! And, I don't just mean Russian...
Burn them. Now!
Well, it looks like they choose us to go out against.
Krasivyy! It has been too long since I looked a Rusalka in the face before I shot it.
@BATTLE
Are you waiting for something?
Those 52-Ks, Kapitan! When will they arrive?
When they arrive. The Commissariat is taking things slowly for now.
You know I hate waiting...
You've certainly gotten better at it.
Oh, just you wait and see, Kapitan! I'm determined to be the most patient Belle there ever was!
Is that why you've been standing up here for hours?
I can almost see the supply ship now...
Kapitan?
Boiky.
Kapitan, it's just occurred to me... What do you want out of all this?
The same thing anyone wants, of course. Peace and safety.
Well, I suppose... I mean, I guess, in the end... But, doesn't that strike you as... Well... Boring?

Fields.MenuText: It strikes me as safe.
You act like there won't be any more challenges.
You'd rather spend each day battling Morganas?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, of course, but... Nothing ever came of safety! Someone's got to strike back to strike at all...
Of course there will be! It's my duty to the revolution to issue them.
You tempt me ever so, but the bourgeoisie are the greater threat in the long run!
You know, there's only so much you can do for the revolution at sea.
V tochku! That is why I cannot possibly rest. Why I am prepared to beach myself and fire on the hearts of the cities of man, should I have cause!
Coming from anyone else, that would be a terrifying statement.
What good fortune it comes from me, ne tak li?
Especially after how considerably you've calmed down.
Me? Calm down? Kapitan, I think you've had a little too much of my Kiev cake!
When we started this tour, I couldn't get you to sit still for a moment. But, it's been several missions now and you haven't blown up anything that belongs to us.
I... I wonder why that is! Clearly my overwhelming victories have made me decadent!
That's not what I was going to say. It's a good thing...
Enough! Kapitan, I must purge my laziness in fire! There are Rusalki near that will do quite nicely...
@BATTLE
Kapitan, what are these crates up on the deck?
Just took them aboard from a supply ship out of Leningrad. Call it a gift.
For me? You shouldn't have!
Now, how do you know they're for you?
Because they are bigger than I am! Who else on board has such large tastes?

Fields.MenuText: Have you asked any of the crew?
I guess I can't slip anything past you.
You don't even know what's in the boxes.

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet. I have been too busy trying to guess!
Ha! The vigilance of Boiky strikes again!
Ne vazhno. If it's something I dislike I can always burn it. Then it will be something I like again!
Open them.
Menya?
You.
Ooh, kak udivitel'no! Reveal your secrets, mysterious boxes!
Kapitan... This muzzle brake... And, look at the caliber on this... Kapitan, you didn't!
All I did was recommend a robust testing environment for the 52-Ks. The Commissariat agreed.
How did you do this? I know everything that goes on aboard me!
Not when you're diligently researching riddles.
When can we have these installed? When, when, when?
Not in time for these Morganas, but soon enough.
@BATTLE
Oh, what a joy it will be to see these installed!
I knew you'd be excited. We haven't had a suitable replacement for the B-13s yet, but this will be a start.
Kapitan... Can I fire them as soon as they're installed? Just once?

Fields.MenuText: I promised the Commissariat a field test. That means against enemies.
Just once. You'll need to choose your target carefully.
You know better than anyone that these aren't toys.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose it's fortunate it never takes the Rusalki long to show up.
I always do, Kapitan! Even if it doesn't look that way...
Can they not be toys and tools both?
Just watch yourself. Command and the Commissariat are both keeping an eye on their performance.
Speaking of performance...
@BATTLE
Once my new guns are installed, we'll really give Kuznetsov something to write about!
The better we can equip you, the quicker we can end this.
Are you still on about that?
About what?
Peace! You don't honestly think we Belles will be content with pleasure cruises once the Rusalki lie at the bottom of the sea?
Well, no, but this war ought to teach the world something. We need each other more than we hate each other.
Heh... That is what I like about you, Kapitan. I know you do not mean any of that.
What are you talking about? Of course I do!
You and I both know that the time is coming for a violent overthrow of the old orders. You prepare for war, yet you preach peace as an ideal. It will come, but not in our time.
We'll have to agree to disagree on that.
See? You have one foot in fantasy and one foot in bloody, messy reality. If only everyone thought as you do!
I find it quite attractive.
Really? Thanks, Boiky.
A revolutionary must speak her mind and her heart. A shame I did not speak mine to you a little bit sooner, but it is the truth, Kapitan.
I feel close to you, too, Boiky.
And I need a favor from you. When we get to port, I need you to distract me from thinking about those guns. I'll be full of energy and far too impatient, you see.
I think I understand...
Can you think of anything the two of us could do together to pass the time?
We've earned some time off. I'm sure we could have fun spending it together somewhere, just you and me...
You and me... and also sweets. Do not forget those!
